div.p: The mule cart on Euclid Avenue began to carry passengers in 1887. The cart went all the way up to 24th Street, thus allowing residents to go to and from jobs, homes, and downtown Ontario. It was also called the “gravity mule cart” because the trolley relied on gravity on its way back down. In 1895 the mules were replaced by electricity. This innovative cart was a pivotal part of the colony’s development. It was the first form of transportation, thus allowing easier access to places to its residents. It was specially important for the development of minority communities in the area, such as the Mexican community. The trolley allowed Mexican residents to travel to the barrio. Thus, this cart helped the community keep its roots and its support for one another.
